metadata.title: Synthesis of composite iron nano adsorbent and removal of ibuprofen drug residue from water

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Molecular Liquids
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /mol l iq
Synthesis of composite iron nano adsorbent and removal of ibuprofen drug residue from water
Imran Ali a,⁎, Zeid A. AL-Othman b, Abdulrahman Alwarthan b
a Department of Chemistry, Jamia Millia Islamia (Central University), New Delhi 110025, India b Department of Chemistry, College of Science, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: drimran.chiral@gmail.com, drimran
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2016.04.031 0167-7322/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 12 March 2016 Accepted 11 April 2016 Available online xxxx
Ibuprofen drug residue is found in somewater resources, which is toxic to human beings and flora and fauna. The removal of ibuprofen drug residue from water is carried out on composite iron nano adsorbent. The composite iron nano adsorbent was prepared by green technology and characterized by FT-IR, XRD, SEM, TEM and EDX techniques. The residual ibuprofen in water was analyzed by HPLC using new generation Sunshell C18 column (150 × 4.61 mm; 2.6 μm). The optimized batch experimental parameters were 60 μg L−1, 30.0 min., 7.0, 1.0 g L−1, and 25.0 °C as concentration, contact time, pH, adsorbent amount and temperature. Adsorption data followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. Thermodynamic parameter ΔG° values were −10.23, −10.24 and −10.26 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures. The values of ΔH° and ΔS° were −2.71 and 24.20 × 10−3. These values indicated favorable and exothermic sorption. Pseudo-first-order and liquid film diffusionmechanisms of the adsorption were proposed. Developedmethodwas speedy, environment friendly and inexpensive due to its nature to be used under natural conditions of water resourceswith 92% removal of ibuprofen. Moreover, ease of desorptionmade this adsorbent recyclable. The developedmethodmay be useful for the removal of ibuprofen drug residue from natural water resources at pHs 7.0 with low adsorbent amount and agitating time. The sorptionmethodmay be used for the removal of ibuprofen from any water body at large and economic scale.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Ibuprofen sorption Adsorption isotherms Kinetics and thermodynamics Water treatment Composite iron nano adsorbent

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Water pollution due to several drugs and pharmaceuticals residues is alarming issue. It is due to the facts that these residues affect some biological activities including disturbance in enzymatic, hormonal and genetic systems of human beings [1]. Amongst various drugs, the profens are being used worldwide due to a large number of arthritis patients. Amongst the profens, ibuprofen is widely prescribed drug. Therefore, water bodies at someplaces are contaminated due to ibuprofen residues [2–4]. Ibuprofen has serious side effects if reached our body through contaminated water. The most prevalent adverse effects of ibuprofens are vomiting, gastric ulceration, bleeding, dyspepsia, bowel inflammation, mucosal damages, kidney problems, cardiovascular risks and central nervous system troubles [5]. Besides, ibuprofen has adverse effect on flora and fauna responsible for climate change. Therefore, the removal methods for ibuprofen drug residue are essentially required. Literature survey indicates only few methods of ibuprofen drug residue removal. These include degradation [6,7] and adsorption methods [8]. It was observed that the reported methods for ibuprofen drug residue are not effective as degradation by-products may be toxic. Contrarily,
_ali@yahoo.com (I. Ali).
the only one adsorption method is not capable to work under natural water conditions.
Therefore, the removalmethod of ibuprofen drug residue in water is demanding in the present scenario. Amongst many methods, adsorption is supposed as the best one due to its several salient features [9–16]. Nowadays, nano adsorbents are gaining importance in water treatment through adsorption. It is due to their remarkable capacities to uptake a wide variety of pollutants [17]. In view of these facts, the efforts have been made to synthesize and characterize composite iron nano adsorbent for the removal of ibuprofen drug residue from water. The findings are discussed herein.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and reagents
sections.text:
The chemicals and reagents used in this study were of HPLC and A.R. grades. Methanol, ethanol, 2-propranolol, n-hexane, acetonitrile, triethylamine and acetic acid were purchases from Merck, Mumbai, India. Black tea was purchased from market. FeSO4, epichlorohydrin and carboxymethyl cellulose were obtained from Qualigens Mumbai, India. Millipore water was prepared using Millipore-Q, Bedford, MA, USA system. Ibuprofen standard was obtained from Ajanta Pharma,
Mumbai, India. Polypropylene membrane (pore size-0.1 μm) was procured from GVS Filtration Technology, Italy.

sections.heading: 2.2. Instruments
sections.text: All the experiments were carried out on an HPLC system of Shimadzu (Japan) consisting of solvent delivery pump (LC-10 AT VP), manual injector, UV-VIS detector (SPD-10 A) with system controller (SCL-10AVP ver 5.33) and Class VP software. Sunshell C18 column (150 × 4.61 mm; 2.6 μm) was of Chromanik, Japan. Besides, other instruments such as sonicator, digital pH meter, centrifuge machine, weighing balance, UV–Visible spectrophotometer, thermostatic water bath shaker and magnetic stirrer were also used.

sections.heading: 2.3. Preparation of composite iron nanocomposite adsorbent
2.3.1. Biosynthesis of iron nanoparticles by green method
sections.text: 30.0 g Black tea was boiled with 500mLMillipore water at 80 °C for 1 h. It was cooled and filtered through Whatman no.1 filter paper. The tea extract was added to 0.1 M FeSO4 solution in ratio of 2:1 with constant stirring for 1 h. A change in color from faint yellow to blackish brown was observed, which indicated the formation of iron nanoparticles. The iron nanoparticles were separated by centrifugation and washedwithMilliporewater. Lastly, thesewere air dried and converted it into powder form.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Synthesis of composite iron Nano adsorbent
sections.text: 1.0 g of Iron nanoparticleswere added in 1.5mLepichlorohydrin and 20mL 20% acetic acid. This mixture was stirred for 24 h followed by the addition of 1.0 g carboxymethylcellulose (CMC) with constant stirring for 5min. The reactionmixturewas allowed to stand for 24 h. The product was dried at 60 °C.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Characterization of composite iron Nano adsorbent
sections.text: The synthesized composite iron nano adsorbent was characterized using FT-IR, XRD, TEM, SEM and EDX techniques.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Preparation of ibuprofen solutions
sections.text: The solutions of ibuprofenwere prepared in the concentration range of 10–80 μg L−1. The other diluted standards solutions for HPLC were prepared from 0.01 to 0.01 mg L−1.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Adsorption studies
sections.text:
The removal of ibuprofen was carried out in batchmode using thermostatic water bath shaker. The iron nano composite particles were separated by centrifugation.HPLCwas used tomonitor equilibriumconcentrations of ibuprofen. The adsorption isotherms were studied at 10–60 min. Contact time, 10–80 μg L−1. concentrations, 3–9 pHs, 0.1–2.0 g L−1 dose and 20.0–30.0 °C temperatures. Thermodynamics and kinetics parameters were evaluated by different models. Equilibrium concentrations of ibuprofenwere calculated using the following formula
Ce ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ=m ð1Þ
where, Ci, Ct, Ce and m are the initial, at particular time (t) and equilibrium amounts (mg L−1) of ibuprofen and weight of adsorbent (g L−1). Percentage removals of ibuprofen were determined by the following equation.
%Removal ¼ Ci−Ctð Þ=C0½ 100 ð2Þ
where, Ci and Ct have the usual meanings.

sections.heading: 2.3.6. Kinetics studies
sections.text: Kinetics profiles of ibuprofen were done by uptake at various time periods. The ranges of the concentrations of ibuprofen were shaken with known amount of iron nano composite adsorbent till equilibrium. Residual ibuprofen were observed using HPLC. Erlenmeyer flasks (100.0 mL) with definite and known concentrations of ibuprofen were shaken on thermostatic water bath shaker. The solutions were centrifuged and the supernatantwas analyzed for ibuprofen. The blank experiments were carried out for determining the experimental errors.

sections.heading: 2.3.7. HPLC determination
sections.text: The different concentrations of ibuprofen were determined by HPLC as discussed above. Separation was performed on Sunshell C18 column (150 × 4.61 mm; 2.6 μm). The mobile phase used in this study was phosphate buffer (10 mM, pH 7.0):acetonitrile (70:30, v/v) at 1.0 mL min−1 flow rate with detection at 220 nm. The mobile phase was filtered and degassed daily before use. Chromatographic parameters, such as capacity (k), separation (α), and resolution (Rs) factors were calculated by using standard chromatographic equations.

sections.heading: 3.1. Biosynthesis of iron nanoparticles using tea extract
sections.text: Iron nanoparticles have been prepared by green synthesis [18,19]. The polyphenol and caffeine contents of tea extract having antioxidant properties served both as reducing and capping agents. The nanoparticles [Fe(II) to Fe(0)] were prepared with 90% yield.

sections.heading: 3.2. Synthesis of composite iron Nano adsorbent
sections.text: The composite nano sorbent was prepared using synthesized iron nanoparticles and carboxymethyl cellulose using epichlorohydrin as cross linker. The nanocomposite formed had a yield of 90%. First epichlorohydrin was reacted with iron nanoparticles providing chloro functional group for further reaction with carboxymethyl cellulose. The oxygen group of carboxymethyl cellulose was reacted with chloro group of epichlorohydrin; resulting into composite ironnano adsorbent.

sections.heading: 3.3. Characterization
sections.text:
The prepared iron nano composite adsorbent was characterized using FT-IR, XRD, TEM, and SEM-EDX analyses. The results are given in the following paragraphs.
The functional groups of composite iron nano adsorbent were identified using FT-IR. Itwas observed that the peakswere ranged from4000 to 400 cm−1. The peaks at 3460 cm−1 and 1637 cm−1 indicated the presence of hydroxyl and ketonic functional groups. Another peak at 1058 cm−1 showed the attendance of an alcoholic C\\O stretching. These results confirmed the formation of composite iron nano adsorbent. The results of XRD analysis of composite iron nano adsorbent indicated the peaks at 2θ values of 18.5 and 44.9. These were corresponded to the occurrence of FeOOH and Fe0 (zero valent iron), respectively. The XRD results also confirmed the amorphous nature of the composite iron nano adsorbent.
SEM analysis was carried out to ascertain the surface morphology of the iron composite nano adsorbent. The SEM images of the composite iron nano adsorbent at different magnifications are given in Fig. 1a and b. The SEM images were recorded at 5000 and 15,000 magnifications. The morphological, topographical and crystalline information was obtained by TEM analysis. The results of TEM analysis are shown in Fig. 2a and b at 10,000 K magnification; showing the morphology and single particle size. Themorphology of the composite iron nano adsorbent was smooth. Furthermore, it can be observed from this figure that composite iron nanoparticles had size varied from 13.7 to 90.3 nm. The elemental composition of the composite iron nano
adsorbent was ascertained by EDX analysis. The spectrum is shown in Fig. 3. This figure clearly shows the attendance of carbon, chlorine, iron, oxygen and sodium in the composite iron nano adsorbent. These signals were due to the X-ray emission from composite iron nanoparticle, which had been tailored using epichlorohydrin as a cross-linker. The emergence of gold element in spectrum was owing to the fact that the samples were coated with gold before analysis.
Fig. 2. TEM images of composite iron nano adsorben

sections.heading: 3.4. HPLC analysis
sections.text: The remaining amount of ibuprofen in adsorption experiments was determined by qualitative and quantitative analyses as per the standard protocol [20]. The retention time was 11.0 min.

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption optimization
sections.text: To optimize the adsorption of ibuprofen drug residue, various variables were varied. These include effects of concentration, contact time, pH, dosage and temperature. The results of these variations are discussed in the following paragraphs.

sections.heading: 3.5.1. Effect of concentration
sections.text: For effect of concentration, the values were varied from 10 to 80 μg L−1. The other parameters used were 30 min contact time, 7.0 pH, 1.0 g L−1 dose and 298 K temperature. The outcome of this operation is shown in Fig. 4a. An examination of this figure dictates the adsorptions 10, 20, 29, 37.5, 46.5 and 55.5 μg/g at 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 and 60 μg L−1 concentrations. Further increase of concentration up to 80 μg L−1 could not enhanced the adsorption. Therefore, 60 μg L−1 concentration was chosen for the rest of the experiments.

sections.heading: 3.5.2. Effect of contact time
sections.text: For effect of contact time, the values were varied from 5 to 60 min. The other parameters used were 60 μg L−1 concentration, 1.0 g L−1 dose, 7.0 pH and 298 K temperature. The outcome of this operation is shown in Fig. 4b. An examination of this figure dictates adsorptions 24, 36, 48 and 55.5 at 5, 10, 20 and 30 min. Further increase in contact could not increase adsorption. Therefore, 30 min contact time was chosen for the rest of the experiments.

sections.heading: 3.5.3. Effect of pH
sections.text: For effect of pH, the valueswere varied from3 to 9. The other parameters used were 30min contact time, 60 μg L−1 concentration, 1.0 g L−1 dose, and 298 K temperature. The outcome of this operation is shown in Fig. 4c. An examination of this figure dictates the adsorptions 24, 33, 41, 50 and 55.5 at 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 pHs. Further increase in pH could not increase adsorption. Therefore, 7.0 pH was chosen for the rest of the experiments.

sections.heading: 3.5.4. Effect of dosage
sections.text:
For effect of dose, the values were varied from 0.1 to 2.0 g L−1. The other parameters usedwere 30min contact time, 7.0 pH, 60 μg L−1 concentration and 298 K temperature. The outcome of this operation is shown in Fig. 4d. An examination of this figure dictates the adsorptions 27.5, 37.5, 48 and 55.5 at 0.1, 0.25, 0.5 and 1.0 g L−1. Further increase in dose could not augment adsorption. Therefore, 1.0 g L−1 dose was chosen for the rest of the experiments.
t (a): surface morphology and (b): particle size.

sections.heading: 3.5.5. Effect of temperature
sections.text:
For effect of temperature, the values were 293, 298 and 303 K. The other parameters usedwere 30min contact time, 7.0 pH, 60 μg L−1 concentration, and 1.0 g L−1 dose. The results of this process are shown in Fig. 3e. It was observed that adsorption was same at all the three temperatures for 10 and 20 μg L−1 concentrations. However, the adsorption started to decrease on increasing temperature. The adsorption order was 293 N 298 N 303 K.
An analysis of all the optimized parameters indicated that the developed adsorptionmethodwas eco-friendly asmost of water bodies have 7.0 pH and temperature in the range of 293–303 K.

sections.heading: 3.6. Modeling of adsorption
sections.text:
The uptake analysis of ibuprofen was studied by applying Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin andDubinin-Radushkevichmodels at three temperatures i.e. 20, 25, 30 °C. The equations related to these models are summarized below:
Langmuir
1=Qt ¼ 1=XmbCt þ 1=Xm: ð3Þ
Dimensionless constants or separation factor (RL).
RL ¼ 1= 1þ bCeð Þ: ð4Þ
Freundlich
logQt ¼ 1=nð ÞlogCt þ logkF: ð5Þ
Temkin
Qt ¼ RT=BTð Þ lnCtþ RT=BTð ÞlnKT: ð6Þ
Dubinin-Radushkevich
lnQt ¼ lnqm−βε2 ð7Þ
ε ¼ RTln 1þ 1=Ctð Þ ð8Þ
E ¼ 1=√ −2βð Þ: ð9Þ
Ct and Qt are concentration and amount adsorbed of ibuprofen at time t. Xm (μg/g) and b (L/μg) are Langmuir constants. The values of Xm and b were estimated using slope and intercept of graph of 1/Qt vs 1/Ct (Fig. 5a). Langmuir model described the results perfectly. The values of these constants are summarized in Table 1. These values confirmed the applicability of Langmuirmodel. The values of Langmuir constant Xm (μg/g) were 66.67, 62.5 and 58.82 at 20, 25 and 30 0 °C, temperatures. The values of constant b (L/μg) were 1.67, 0.89 and 0.77 at 20, 25 and 30 0 °C, temperatures. The dimensionless constants were 0.15, 0.19 and 0.20 at 20, 25 and 30 0 °C, temperature. All these data indicated a good sorption. n and kF [(μg/g)] are Freundlich coefficients related to relative adsorption capacities and sorption intensities. The intercept and slope of the graph of logQt vs logCt (Fig. 5b) relate to kF and 1/n. The values of Freundlich coefficients (Table 1) confirmed favorable sorption. Furthermore, these values also confirmed low sorption at high temperature. KT (L/g) and BT (kJ/mol) are coefficients of maximumbinding energy and heat of sorption. KT and BTwere calculated from intercept and slope of Fig. 5c. The values of KT and BT (Table 1) confirmed a good variation in heat of sorption and good interactions between adsorbate and adsorbent. qm and E corresponded to degree and average energy of sorption permole of adsorbate. Thesewere calculated from intercept and slop of Fig. 5d. The E values were ranged from 1.0 to 1.32 kJ/mol (Table 1); indicating physical sorption.

sections.heading: 3.7. Adsorption thermodynamic
sections.text:
Free energy, enthalpy and entropy were calculated by
ΔG0 ¼ −RTlnÅQ ð10Þ
lnQÅ¼ ΔS0=R−ΔH0=RT: ð11Þ
T, R and Q° (Xm) are absolute temperature (K), universal gas constant (0.008314 kJ/mol K−1) and Langmuir constant. Graph of lnQ° vs 1/T was a straight line (not shown). The intercept and slop connected to ΔH° and ΔS°. The values of free energy, enthalpy and entropy are
given in Table 2. The values of free energy and enthalpy were negative while the values of entropy were positive. These sign clearly indication of adsorption spontaneous at all the temperatures. Furthermore, the negative free energy and enthalpy values showed exothermic adsorption.

sections.heading: 3.8. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text:
The sorption kinetics was determined by the following models. Pseudo-first-order kinetic
log Qe−Qtð Þ ¼ logQe–k1 t=2:303 ð15Þ
Pseudo-second order kinetic model
t=Qt ¼ 1=hþ t=Qe: ð18Þ
Elovich's kinetic model
Qt ¼ 1=βln αβð Þ þ 1=βlnt: ð19Þ
The equilibrium rate constant [k1 (min−1)] was calculated from slop of log(Qe− Qt) vs t graph (Fig. 6a). Pseudo-first order rate constant and regression coefficient (R2) were 0.094 (min−1) and 0.999 confirming this model. The experimental and theoretical values of equilibrium amounts were 55.5 and 66.67 μg/g; with 7.88% higher theoretical value i.e. nearly close to each other. This observation could made pseudo-first order kinetic model as the best one. However, pseudosecond order kinetic model was also applied to the experimental data. The initial (h) and overall rate (k2) constants were calculated from pseudo second order (Fig. 6b). k2 (rate constant) andQewere calculated from intercept and slope of t/Qt vs t graph. The value of h was calculated as reciprocal of intercept. The values of k2were smaller than the value of k1 (Table 3) indicating no-applicability of second pseudo order reaction.
Moreover, a high difference of 20.13% between theoretical and practical values of amount adsorbed showed non-applicability of pseudo second order model.
Adsorption and desorptionwere ascertained by Eq. 19whereα (mg/ g/min) and β (g/mg) were adsorption and desorption rate constants. α and β values were 25.70 and 0.055 (Table 3) indicated that adsorption was stronger than desorption. The regression constantwas 0.967 showing the applicability of Elovich's kinetic model.

sections.heading: 3.9. Adsorption mechanism
sections.text:
The sorption mechanism was ascertained by -. Intraparticle diffusion kinetic model
Qt ¼ kipdt05: ð20Þ Liquid film diffusion kinetic model
ln 1−Fð Þ ¼ −kfdt ð21Þ
The uptake of ibuprofen to adsorption siteswas studied by Eq. 20 (Qt vs t0.5). The rate constant was 9.62 μg g−1 min−0.5. Regression
coefficient and intercept were 0.987 and 3.0 (Table 3). Graph line could not pass through the origin; showing non-applicability of intraparticle diffusionmodel. kfd and F=Qt/Qe is film diffusion rate constant and fractional attainment of equilibrium. Intercept and kfd values were 0.1 and 0.1 (Table 3). These values showed that adsorption was occurred through diffusion phenomenon. The straight line of ln(1-F) vs t graph deviated by only 0.01 magnitude; indicating the nearness to the origin. This deviationmight be due to high agitation during batch experiments and disparity between rates of mass transfer in starting and last stages. Such deviations have already been described in various research papers [21–24]. Hence, uptake of ibuprofenwas considered to be by liquid film diffusion mechanism.

sections.heading: 3.10. Regeneration of composite iron Nano adsorbent
sections.text:
The economic status of composite iron nano adsorbent was ascertained by recycling method. High value of β indicated good desorption properties of the composite nano adsorbent. For this, regeneration of composite iron nano adsorbentwas achieved by treating it with dilute acids such as HCl, HNO3 and H2SO4. Additionally, bases like sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxides were also tried for regeneration of the adsorbent. Besides, some buffers such as phosphate, citrate,
acetate were also tested for this application. After many experiments, it was practical that the best regenerating solventwas 0.50Nhydrochloric acid. It was capable to regenerate up to 98% adsorbent. The regenerated adsorbent was used up to 8 batch operations with the removal capacities from 85 to 92%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The developed composite iron nano adsorbent was effective for the uptake of ibuprofen from aqueous solutionwithmaximum 92% adsorption. The sorption was spontaneous with exothermic in nature. The optimized batch parameters were 60 μg L−1, 30.0 min., 7.0, 1.0 g L−1 and 25.0 °C as concentration, contact time, pH, adsorbent amount and temperature. Adsorption data followed Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich models. Thermodynamic parameter ΔG° values were−10.23, −10.24 and −10.26 kJ/mol at 20, 25 and 30 °C temperatures. The values of ΔH° and ΔS° were −2.71 and 24.20 × 10−3.
These values clearly indicated adsorption spontaneous at all the temperatures. Pseudo-first-order and liquid film diffusion mechanisms of the adsorption were proposed. Developed sorption method was fast, environmental friendly and inexpensive due to its nature to work under natural conditions of water resources. The method is capable to work at natural water resources pHs with low adsorbent and agitating time. The sorption method may be used for the removal of ibuprofen from any water body at large and economic scale.

sections.text: The authors are thankful to King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia for visiting professorship programme.
